articles.title: Messaging through Hurricane Melissa
articles.summary: I know what's happening on the ground in Jamaica thanks to WhatsApp â€” ordinarily, a quick and convenient means of staying in touch; under threat of natural a disaster, a lifeline.
articles.content:
On Monday October 20, Melissa, then a tropical storm, was ambling across the central Caribbean. Jamaica's meteorological office had put out the requisite news release advising of a severe weather alert. Fishers should expect â€œdeterioratingâ€ sea conditions and residents, â€œperiods of heavy rainfall and strong, gusty winds.â€ Just over a week later, as Hurricane Melissa approaches the Caribbean island, it is impossible to access the met office's website: â€œToo Many Requests,â€ the message says. â€œThe user has sent too many requests in a given amount of time.â€

Yet, I know what's happening on the ground in Jamaica thanks to the messaging service of choice in the Caribbean, WhatsApp. Ever since that initial press release, I have been regularly staying in touch with family and friends, two of whom â€” Emma Lewis and Candice Stewart â€” are cherished Global Voices contributors. Ordinarily, the messaging app is a quick and convenient means of staying in touch. Under threat of a natural disaster, it's a lifeline.

By Tuesday October 21, we could see where things were heading. Even as Emma shared photos of an â€œextraordinary sunriseâ€ against â€œdark clouds on the horizon,â€ making sure to tell us she used no filters, just her iPhone, Jamaica's parliament was in an uproar, with the opposition marching out of the sitting following a heated debate over hurricane readiness. The government subsequently had press conferences to address the national disaster preparedness roll-out plan.

Meanwhile, in sharing a colourful screenshot from WeatherNerds.org on our chat, Emma quipped, â€œI guess all these scribbles meanâ€¦HELP!!â€ By Friday, she had deemed the latest forecast from the National Hurricane Center in Florida â€œhorrible.â€ Prime Minister Andrew Holness soon declared Jamaica a â€œthreatened area,â€ followed by the issuing of a trade order to prevent price gouging. The order prohibits retailers from increasing the price of essential goods like food, water, medical supplies, personal care items, building materials, and emergency equipment.

On Friday October 24, with Melissa expected to â€œrapidly intensify,â€ Jamaicaâ€™s met office put the country under a hurricane warning. â€œYup!â€ Emma mused. â€œNervous now.â€ To which Candice replied, â€œI'm trying not to feed into nerves or anxiety because it'll be a wrap if I get there.â€

From last year's experience with Hurricane Beryl, it was obvious that even though Emma and Candice live in the same country, their experiences of the same storm were very different. Emma lives in the capital, Kingston, which is much more urban with well established infrastructure, while Candice is further inland, in the parish of St. Catherine. After the passage of Beryl, Candice lost access to pipe-borne water for an extended period of time. In the early hours of Tuesday October 28, Candice posted, â€œThat's it for water in the pipes.â€ The storm had not yet made landfall.

As with Beryl, Candice was prepared to change location quickly if needed. As Emma cautioned, â€œSome areas are likely to flood. Plus storm surgeâ€¦â€ Candice reminded her, â€œI'm inland [â€¦] away from storm surges, but I fear that if [Melissa] stays the path of what I currently see on the Zoom Earth storm tracker, I'll be close to her centre when she passes through.â€ Beryl, she remembered, more or less â€œskirtedâ€ Jamaica. â€œThis oneâ€¦.bwoooooyyy!â€ Of concern with Melissa is not just the size and path of the storm, but the fact that it is very slow-moving. â€œYou might have landslides, Candice,â€ Emma said, concerned. â€œTrying not to sit on that possibility too much,â€ she replied. â€œThe stress aloneâ€¦â€

As part of the hurricane prep, Jamaica was welcoming teams of linesmen from the United States, Canada and St. Vincent and the Grenadines to assist the Jamaica Public Service (JPS), the sole electricity provider on the island, with restoration of power in the wake of the storm. After Hurricane Beryl, certain communities â€” in Jamaica as well as the wider region â€” were left without power for months.

Saturday October 25: Melissa is upgraded to hurricane status, prompting Candice to share in the wee hours of Sunday morning, â€œStruggling to stay asleep. Usually when this happens, I'd hear birds outside brooding, or some insect chirping or whatever noise they make. You know, something to blend as white noise in my headâ€¦it's dead silent. I'm scared.â€

Emma replied, â€œOur frogs are still tweeting but apart from that itâ€™s been strangely quiet all day, not a breath of wind. But my friend Carla tells me itâ€™s very rough, windy weather in eastern Portland.â€ Within an hour of that conversation, Melissa had been upgraded to a Cat 3 storm. â€œItâ€™s nerve-wracking,â€ Emma continued. â€œThis morning is calm in Kingston but nonstop rain since last night. Eastern parishes are getting stormy conditions.â€

â€œBeen drizzling on my side since around 6 a.m.,â€ Candice replied. â€œNot much breeze. Dark skies. Haven't slept since my last check-in. Mostly anxiety. ğŸ« â€ Emma admitted she had â€œslept really badly tooâ€: â€œRaining nonstop here but no breeze yet. Itâ€™s also getting darker.â€ The irony, as Candice noted, was that â€œoutside just looks like one of those rainy days. The type that I live for, esp. when I'm home. However, knowing what's behind [it] all is the real pressure raiser.â€

Over the next couple of days, they would share links of how the country's zookeepers were prepping the facilities to keep the animals safe, marvel at entrepreneurial Jamaicans who were using WhatsApp to offer their services for last-minute roof patching jobs, and remember the passage of Hurricane Gilbert in 1988: â€œIt was chaotic,â€ Emma recalls. â€œPeople werenâ€™t used to hurricanes then (they are now!!) I recall lining up outside the Ice Factory downtown to get a block of ice. No power or water for quite a while. We pulled through thoughâ€¦â€

In true Caribbean style, humour also came into play â€” or as Jamaicans put it, â€œTek serious ting mek laughâ€ â€” even as evacuation orders were being issued for certain high-risk communities. By Monday October 27, Candice informed us, â€œWinds have picked up significantly. It's literally howling. I suspect the power will be out soon. I'm good. Fed, cosy but alert, and also much more rested.â€

â€œWindy down here,â€ Emma replied, â€œbut weâ€™re not howling yet. I hardly slept (again). Itâ€™s a Category Five.â€ Flooding soon began to besiege certain communities, with â€œquite a few crocodile sightings in flood waters.â€ Candice added, â€œAnd there's a chance that other endemic species and just animals all round will get dislocated and be all over. I don't have to be concerned about crocs, but I wouldn't be surprised if I see snakes. I [remember] post-Ivan, crabs were all over the verandah.â€

Mostly, though, the messaging filled the spaces in between the waiting as Candice mused, â€œâ€™51 storm Charlie â€“ Cat 3; â€™88 storm Gilbert â€“ hit us as a Cat 3; â€25 storm Melissa â€“ maybe Cat 5, maybe Cat 4. All 37 years apart and all had some significant impact. Once a generation ğŸ¤·ğŸ¾â€â™€ï¸. It feels kind of personal [â€¦] Two years in a row our breadbasket parish is gonna get a lashing.â€

According to Emma, the country's Office of Disaster Preparedness and Emergency Management has been doing a stellar job, including regularly communicating the met office's updates on its social media channels.

In the prelude to the storm, Jamaica has already had three deaths â€” two caused by falling tress, and one by an electrocution incident â€” and 13 injuries, mostly from people falling off ladders or rooftops. All health centres have been closed, but all major hospitals on the island remain open. Additionally, out of over 800 shelters scattered across the country, about 130 have been made operational, with Candice expecting that number to increase very soon. Psychosocial support is also being provided to citizens via the country's health ministry and, as should be expected in the age of AI, fake disaster videos have been proliferating on social media as the storm bears down on the island.

By Tuesday October 28, the predicted date of landfall, Candice updated the chat: â€œOutside a blow weh and tumble down. The howling ğŸ˜©ğŸ˜©ğŸ˜©ğŸ˜© [â€¦] Gusts getting stronger.â€ Emma added, â€œWind is now quite fierce in Kingston and I'm hearing a lot of strange noises outside. Have not slept at all. Now getting very heavy rain.â€ As at the time of publishing, Emma, who relies on solar, still had power; Candice's electricity went at 9:47 a.m. local time. â€œPhysically I'm okay,â€ she reported. â€œSafe [but] emotionally wrecked. This wind is haunting.â€

An early morning bulletin advised that conditions would â€œcontinue to deteriorate ahead of landfall,â€ which is expected to be sometime this afternoon. As several WhatsApp messages circulated around the region asking for prayers, Candice said, â€œIdk how we'll overcome. I know we will, I just don't know how.â€

articles.personality_title: WhatsApp helps Jamaicans stay connected and prepared during Hurricane Melissa
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** â€“ In October 2023, Hurricane Melissa threatened Jamaica with heavy rain, strong winds, and flooding. The island faced challenges preparing for the storm, including overloaded official websites and power outages.

**What happened** â€“ As the hurricane approached, Jamaicans used WhatsApp, a popular messaging app, to share updates, photos, and safety information. Two contributors, Emma and Candice, exchanged messages describing their different experiences from urban Kingston to inland St. Catherine. The government declared a hurricane warning, restricted price increases on essential goods, and opened shelters. Teams from other countries arrived to help restore power.

**Impact** â€“ WhatsApp became a crucial lifeline, letting people stay informed and support each other when official sources were overwhelmed. The messages showed how communities prepared, shared warnings about flooding and power loss, and even helped find last-minute repairs. This digital connection helped reduce anxiety and gave a clearer picture of the stormâ€™s effects across the island.

**What's next step** â€“ As Melissa made landfall, people continued using WhatsApp to report conditions and check on loved ones. After the storm, recovery efforts will focus on restoring water, power, and services, aided by the teams already on the island. The experience may encourage Jamaica to strengthen communication systems for future emergencies.

**One-sentence takeaway** â€“ During Hurricane Melissa, WhatsApp proved vital for Jamaicans to stay connected, informed, and prepared when official channels struggled to keep up.
